node.text:
Analysing the performance of your vehicle is a critical step when it comes to corner weighting or setup adjustments, but what are some of the key areas you should focus on to check where your car is at?

This is one module from a full course that covers the corner weighting process from start to finish.

In this lesson which is taken from the Practical Corner Weighting course, Andre will cover some of the things he checks at his local track, Highlands Motorsport Park. After this step you will assess your vehicles set up and adjust accordingly, being mindful that you're not trying to fix oversteer or understeer issues that are actually driver induced handling errors.

For this test we're going to use a GG Diagram aka Traction Circle to also help give us an indication if the car is favouring one side or end over the other.

Note any testing should be started at a slow speed while you work up to full pace.

#highperformanceacademy #racecraft #learndriveoptimise #cornerweighting #highlandsmotorsportpark

node.title: What's Wrong Here? | Testing Track Performance [#FREELESSON]

node.text:
The electrification of motorsports is still in its early days, but there is already plenty to talk about.

Battery cooling, cell layout, voltage limitations and the advantages of an electric package over the traditional internal combustion engine approach are just a few of the topics Tim discusses with Hamish Janett of the @ucnz  Formula SAE team.

Seen cutting some laps alongside the @ucmotorsport single seater is Paddon Rallysport's electric Hyundai Kona rally car due to enter competition in 2022.

What is Formula SAE? Also known as FSAE or Formula Student, it is a University level student design competition which is run and governed by SAE International (aka Society of Automotive Engineers International). The concept is to develop a small Formula (single-seat open-wheel car) race car which is then evaluated by a number of different static and dynamic considerations and events.

0:29 - EV vs ICE Advantages
1:08 - FSAE EV Application
1:40 - Layout of EV Components
2:27 - Current and Voltage Range
2:57 - EV Cooling Management
3:50 - Battery Air Cooling Setup
4:24 - Cell Layout vs Cooling
5:07 - Motor Controller and Motor Cooling
5:44 - Water Weight

#highperformanceacademy #formulasae #ev #ucm #electricmotorsports #evracing

node.title: EV's In Motorsport | Formula SAE Electric Single Seater [TECH TALK]

node.text:
Unlike connector boots which are more uniform in shape, transition points are a completely different ball game with a lot more leg work required to ensure you get the correct boot for you specific application and ensure it is fitted correct to achieve the goals of providing strain relief and protection to our wiring harness/loom.

NOTE: This is just ONE module from the Practical Wiring - Professional Motorsport Harness Construction Course.

In this [FREE LESSSON] you're going to get a run down on why we even bother to boot transition points in the first place, 2 of the main boot options on the market being HellermannTyton and Raychem along with some tips on selection and a practical demonstration on an example wiring transition point.

0:00 - Why Do We Boot Transitions?
0:15 - 2 Main Options
0:42 - Raychem vs HellermannTyton
1:15 - Unrecovered Form
1:43 - Shape and Size Selection
2:25 - Our Example Materials
4:32 - Practical Example
16:01 - Final Inspection and Summary

#highperformanceacademy #learntowire #dontletthesmokeout #wiring101 #booting #transition #wiring #motorsportwiring #hellermanntyton #raychem

node.title: Better Than OEM? | Booting Transitions For Motorsport Wiring [FREE #LESSON]

node.text:
Without data, all you have is an opinion and arguably compromised performance.

With systems more popular and cheaper than ever from dedicated data standalone solutions to using a tablet or mobile device, it has never been easier to gather, and the analyze the details in your data. From car setup to driver performance, live mechanical reports and more, you have the power to pinpoint where and how improvements can be made, or when maybe you've hit diminishing gains.

Former #F1 Electronics Technician/2nd Engineer, #V8Supercars #HRT Holden Racing Team Systems Engineer and now @motec_global Operations Manager Ty Anderson runs us through some of the data engineers are watching on their #telemetry screens along with how it is transmitted from car to pits, and vice versa, via cellular or radio signal as well as what some of the key aspects focused on when it comes to sifting through streams and streams of data on race weekend.

0:00 - Telemetry Is Cheaper Than Ever
0:28 - Ty Anderson - MoTeC
1:08 - Background in Formula 1 Telemetry
1:40 - Getting Data From Car to Pits
2:23 - Cellular/3G or 4G vs Radio/VHF
3:32 - What Is Popular Now?
3:54 - Data Security
4:45 - Race Control/Broadcaster Data
5:20 - Marshals Communicating With Drivers
6:03 - Key Data Aspects
7:16 - Safety Alarms/Alerts
7:43 - Driver Training via Data
8:23 - Everything Has Its Place

#highperformanceacademy #telemetry #motec #datanerd #dataanalysis #raceengineer #formula1 #f1 #v8supercars #myprishow  #racetelemetry #motec @motecusa

node.title: Former F1 Data Engineer Explains Race Telemetry | MoTeC [#TECHTALK]

node.text:
So many people get some, or worst case scenario ALL, of these 5 points wrong when selecting and setting up their performance cam/s. So what are they?

1.) Choosing the wrong camshaft
2.) Not setting the timing correctly
3.) No supporting modifications
4.) Incorrect idle speed
5.) Getting it all wrong, then making it worse, with a drill

In this [TECH TALK], firstly, Andre runs us through some of the basic yet so often overlooked questions you need to ask when choosing the correct cam for your application. For example, what application is going to see you wanting an aggressive cam, and when would one actually be detrimental to performance and your vehicles driveability?

Up next is getting the cam timing wrong. An INSANE amount of people spend big money on a cam, then just set it to 0 and send it - not ideal. When incorrect this can at best cause loss of performance (the opposite goal of fitting our cam) and at worst cause valve to piston contact, which is going to cost you much more than the time and tools it takes to do it right. 

Following on from this, it is also important to have the correct supporting components to go along with the bigger cam, valves, higher flow air intake and a freer flowing exhaust system which are generally modifications that are naturally done beforehand anyway, but are missed often enough to make it worth a mention.

The last two common issues we’ve seen countless times revolve around idle tuning. Firstly is targeting an idle that is to low. With the OEM cam out of the picture, and in particular if you have better an aggressive aftermarket cam, the OEM idle speed also needs to go in order to save you hours and hours of trying to make something work that simply never will, or even worse, drilling a hole in your throttle body butterfly as a way to compensate for poor, or non-existent, tuning. Again though, Andre shares the solution to help you make the correct changes and get better results.

#putthedrilldown #highperformanceacademy #learntotune #performancecamtuning #bigcamtuning #performancecam #cam #ls2 #l98 #camshaft

node.title: 5 Things You're Doing WRONG | Camshaft Selection and Tuning [#TECHTALK]

node.text:
...but just a little bit of time and planning makes all the difference.

This is just ONE module taken from a full motorsport wiring course. Link below.

The points where our harness needs to branch tend to be the most complicated sections to construct tidily especially when branch outs are coming from different layers within your loom and heading off in different directions to the main 'trunk'.

Often, we will strike a situation where a branch will contain wires from multiple different layers of the harness section from which it is branching out of and this can make it difficult to tidily gather those wires together to form our new branch.
 
Our aim is for all the wires to be able to head off down their required branches without seeing any strain at the branch point.
 
In this [FREE LESSON] our local motorsport wiring legend and part-time CAN Bus communication aficionado, Zac, is going to run us all through how to accomplish a satisfactory branching point that is tidy, correctly strain relieved and ready for the next stages of your motorsport wiring harness construction.

Check back in a few weeks for a lesson on the booting steps that Zac touched on in this lesson too.

0:00 - Branching is Hard, This Is Why
0:21 - Our Aim
0:55 - Between Branches
1:07 - Branch Points
1:23 - 2 Most Common Tasks
1:42 - Branch Example
2:38 - Step One: Gathering Wires
4:28 - Lay-up Design Notes
5:51 - Step Two: Securing Branch Sections
7:07 - Step Three: Branch Orientation and Strain Relief
8:32 - Kapton Tape Flexibility Notes
9:10 - Booting Notes
9:34 - Bare Branch Example Takeaway
10:13 - What's next? 
 
#highperformanceacademy #wiring101 #branching #motorsportwiring

node.title: It's So Easy To Get This Wrong | Wiring Harness Branching [#FREELESSON]

node.text:
Want to learn how to tune the cam in your LS V8? Here’s how you can get started...

This is just one module from a comprehensive HPA 'How to Degree your Cam' course. Learn how to degree your own cam on your own specific project or get your money back.

In today's release, we’re going to dive into some details on the Kelford valve springs and HS108-D selected for our LS powered Holden Commodore SS VE project along with some of the supporting modifications that go along with such an upgrade. Also covered are some of the fitment considerations with this project being completed in the engine bay rather than on an engine stand with a fresh build making it relative to a wide range of projects out there.

Andre talks us through the components used/ required in the new cam installation and also talks about the 3 Pieces of info we can use to degree our freshly installed cam. Using our L98 V8 Andre talks about the parts associated with Installing our new Kelford Cam & the timing set used.

#highperformanceacademy #kelfordcams #enginebuilding101 #cams #camshaft #camdegreeing #enginebuilding #ls #lsv8 #holden #gm #hydrauliclifters #camchop #lopeyidle #performancecam Less

node.title: LS V8 Cam Swap | Aggressive Cam Specs and Degreeing [FREE LESSON]

node.text:
If you're setting up your ECU to read the exhaust manifold pressure and you don't have an absolute pressure sensor installed, what #CAN you do?

Zac walks us through how you can use a ‘rough and ready’ setup to calibrate the ECU without pressure sensors by using a variable potentiometer in your latest [#TECHTALK]. In our case, a good trick to know since we're waiting on the correct sensor to arrive, so Zac can get on with the job at hand but there are of course many other use cases for this knowledge too.

#highperformanceacademy #learntotune #enginebuilding101 #dontletthesmokeout #wiring101 #canbus #potentiometers

node.title: Calculating Exhaust Pressure WITHOUT A Pressure Sensor | [#TECHTALK]

node.text:
How does the FIA mandate fairness between teams competing at LeMans? 

In this week's [#TECHTALK] we go back to the Goodwood Festival of Speed to talk about Parity Control with the LeMans competitors. Andre talks about how the FIA limit the max boost pressure on turbo charged cars and how the important accurate close loop control tuning is to achieve the max boost pressure out of the limits. 

Also talked about is mandating the AFR targets, this can lead to some teams running more on the lean side to sacrifice some power but improve their fuel efficiency - which in an endurance can be important. While talking about leaning out the AFR target, another thing that needs to be considered is the increase in combustion temperature and how this could affect knock. 

#highperformanceacademy #learntotune #enginebuilding101 #dontletthesmokeout #wiring101 #lemans #enduranceracing #paritycontrol #fia

node.title: How does the FIA keep the racing fair? | LeMans Parity Control [#TECHTALK]

node.text:
Here's an ECU, PDM, datalogger, oscilloscope and a wideband controller, all in one unit. Wait....what?!

In this week’s [UNBOXING] Zac walks us through the unboxing of the recently released Haltech NEXUS R5 which we like to refer to as being the Swiss Army Knife of ECUs/VCUs (vehicle control units)

Covered is what is included in the box with the NEXUS R5, the use and application of it and the long and impressive list of features that it packs, including Wifi connectivity, multiple ports and AMP Superseal 1.0 and Deutsch DTP connectors (and a USB C port, nice touch Haltech!) as well as the built-in PMU/PDM and data logger.

Zac also runs through the high current RadLok connectors with some tips on the crimping tool-type he would use for these with the 50mm2/1 AWG along with the physical construction of the NEXUS unit.

On the ECU side of things, the feature list is solid with 12 ignition outputs enabling the unit to be used with any number of cylinders up to a V12 using sequential firing, as well as 18 injector drivers giving a lot of flexibility around staged injection options. The ability to run a dual DBW throttle setup and 2 dedicated knock and wideband control inputs help round off a few more features that lend themselves well to V configurations without the need to add external modules. 
We're happy to report one thing that has also been improved upon when directly compared to the Elite line of ECUs is the connection time according to our personal testing which while only a small annoyance is one that won't be missed.

Included is also the ability to log 150 channels of data at 1kHz with 512MB of onboard space, automatic transmission control along with the PDU/PDM features that include 12 x 8A and 4 x 25A outputs which are software definable and allow PWM operation. Why do you want a PDU? Zac also has you covered on some of the advantages which included a lower cost for a more simplified wiring loom.

#highperformanceacademy #learntotune #haltech #wiring101 #nexusr5 #ecu #pmu #logger #unboxing #techtalk #haltechecu #haltechnexus #pmu #pdm #datalogger #swissarmyecu

node.title: 5 Devices, 1 Box = Industry Game Changer? | Haltech Nexus R5 Unboxing

node.text:
Running 45psi and 4000hp+ on factory leaf springs and 275 radials, this XW Falcon certainly catches some attention.

In this week's [TechTour] Andre talks to Frank from @dandyengines about running Steve Bezzina's  @pro_line_racing  #481X powered Falcon in the ProMod drag series.

First up Andre talks with Frank about the kind speeds the  @fueltechems controlled and  @precisionturbo boosted 540ci 481X Falcon is hitting down the strip with a 6.72 at 216mph achieved at the time of filming at the 2020 Sydney @jamboree_official (which was rained off sadly!). 

From there the stroked Pro Line engine itself is discussed including some of the restrictions teams have to follow in the ProMod category to keep the playing field level for competitors regards of their forced induction/power adder choices or lack of.

Also talked about is the maintenance and time put into looking after these high output engines and how often teams are having to swap out valve springs, con rods and plugs along with how Frank and the team around the car often check the spark plugs to help confirm the data they get from the engine's sensors.

Lastly how strong the billet aluminium blocks these days are along with the ability to repair them if and when required, and how difficult is it to maintain a Pro Line engine outside of the USA are touched on.

At this stage, the size of the @mickeythompsontires 275 radials on @weldwheels the car runs to comply with class rules are the major limiting factors with more power easily on tap to wind up with future development.

#highperformanceacademy #dandyengines #prolineracing #learntotune #enginebuilding101 #xwfalcon #kxw406 #fordfalcoln #precisionturbo #fueltech #promod #x275 #mickeythompson #weldracing

node.title: Maintaining a 4000+HP Proline V8 | Engine Building [TECH TOUR]

node.text:
Are you running EGT sensors? Do you know which ones to use and how to set them up?

In this weeks [TECH TALK] Andre dives into the world of EGT Sensors, what their operating principles are, the data they can provide us and some tips and tricks with them along the way.
First covered is what EGT’s do and a brief history on them. Then we move onto the operating principles and some things to consider around using EGT’s. Andre walks us through a couple of different EGT sensor types, their pro’s and con’s and also the use of thermocouple amplifiers to manage multiple EGT sensor inputs to your ECU.
After that we dive into some data from our GT86 shop car, how important the location of EGT sensors are and how you can actually use EGT sensors to quickly locate a misfire. 

#highperformanceacademy #egt #exhaustgastemperature #sensors #tuning

node.title: Want to learn more about EGT’s?

node.text:
Conventionally on turbo engines we use a wastegate to control boost pressure and a blow off valve (BOV) to release compressed air when the throttle is closed. As technology has advanced we’re now seeing some engines ditching the BOV in favour of a small drive by wire (dbw) throttle body instead. 

The dbw motor can be controlled by the ECU to replicate the functionality of a normal BOV, but with complete control over the opening and closing of the dbw throttle, there are some other advantages too. First up the dbw throttle can be used to help provide stable and consistent boost pressure, particularly during launch when the engine is on the 2 step. For a drag car, consistent and repeatable boost when the car leaves the line is critical to a good 60’. While the exhaust-mounted wastegate can of course be used during the launch phase for boost control, we tend to see oscillations in the boost pressure as a result of the 2 step. In some instances the wastegate is ditched entirely and the dbw throttle is soley in charge of boost control. 

Another issue we can run into with large turbos on small capacity engines is that we can end up running them very close to the surge limit. This is usually not an issue when the car is on a good track, but on poorly prepped tracks the driver may end up short shifting a gear if the cars breaks traction and gets loose. This drops the engine rpm lower in the rev range which can be enough to drive the turbo into surge. Using some clever logic in the ECU the dbw throttle can be opened in these conditions to bypass additional airflow from the turbo and prevent surge. #highperformanceacademy #boostfordays

node.text:
Electronics are not always intuitive and even when you get hands-on often you only get a 'feeling' for something once it has already gone horribly wrong.

In tomorrow's [FREE LESSON] Zac is here to help you with some of the key fundamentals you need to understand before starting any wiring project. These are resistance, current and voltage, and an understading of these is going to carry you through any project or troubleshooting task, big or small.

Make sure your subscribed via the link in our profile to catch this upon release.

#highperformanceacademy #learntowire #motorsportwiring #automotivewiring #dontletthesmokeout #volts #amps #resistance #current

node.text:
One of the considerations when setting up coil over suspension is to make sure that we’re utilising all of the available travel so the suspension can do its job properly. This is where adjusting the lower mount on the strut body comes in (it’s not there to adjust ride height as many people think!). 

By removing the spring we can easily move the suspension through the full range of bump and rebound motion. Ideally we want to make sure that the lower mount is adjusted so that the damper will contact the bump stop before the tire contacts the chassis which will maximise the available bump travel and ensure safety. However what if you don’t want to run your car that low? Well the other aspect we need to consider is the ratio between bump and rebound travel from the normal ride height. While there are a range of factors that contribute to the ideal ratio, a good rule of thumb is to aim for 1/3 or the available travel in rebound (extension) and 2/3 in bump (compression). 

Fortunately when you’re dealing with a well developed product like these @mcasuspension dampers for our #toyota #86 development car, all the hard work is done for you and these are literally a bolt-in deal. 

#highperformanceacademy #fromthearchives #racecraft #learndriveoptimise #suspension101

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by High Performance Academy on September 02, 2021.

node.text:
There's no denying this @alconbrakes caliper is a work of art, but there are also a number of features that are common to many of the top-tier brake caliper manufacturers that are worth discussing.

The first thing you'll notice by looking through these images is that there are no joins in the caliper body - it's all made from a single piece, this is what's reffered to as a mono-block caliper. Having the caliper machined from a single piece of material helps to increase the rigidity for a given caliper weight, this means less compliance in the brake system giving the driver less pedal travel and higher consistency.

Looking closely at the rear side of the caliper (image with the red plastic over the inlet port) you can see that different sized pistons are fitted. This offset in the piston bores is used to change the pressure distribution across the brake pads to reduce tapered pad wear. You can also see some slots on the piston faces, this is to help reduce heat transfer from the pads, to the pistons and therefore the brake fluid.

You'll also notice there are two bleed ports on the back of the caliper. This gives flexibility in the mounting of the caliper, meaning it can be placed either in front or behind the wheel centreline and still have a bleed port at the top of the caliper. If the bleed port is not  at the highest point on the caliper, you won't be able to bleed the brakes which is obviously problematic!

How many of you guys have calipers on your cars with some of these features and what differences did you notice?

#highperformanceacademy #brakes #brakecalipers

node.text:
One of the most critical steps when it comes to tuning an aftermarket standalone ECU is setting the base ignition timing. This step essentially calibrates the ECU so that the timing that we see on the laptop screen is the actual ignition timing being delivered at the spark plug. We’ve lost count of the number of engines we’ve retuned where this step had been omitted and the timing is wrong. We get it, it can be time consuming to do. Particularly on late model engines, access to the ignition coil for #1 cylinder can be tricky, and some engines don’t have timing marks on the crank pulley, meaning we need to make our own which adds another layer of complexity. Lastly, when you’re sitting behind the laptop screen in the comfort of the drivers seat, it can be hard to want to actually grab some tools and get your hands dirty to complete this step. 

So why is it so important? If the ignition timing isn’t calibrated properly then the numbers in the ignition tables will have no relationship to the actual timing the engine is receiving. If the actual timing is less than what’s displayed on the laptop then you’re likely to end up with an engine that doesn’t produce the power it’s capable of. The flip side however is more dangerous when the engine has more timing than the laptop suggests. Particularly for those tuners who don’t use knock detection, this can easily lead to detonation that can damage or destroy your expensive engine. 

We’re using a @snapon_official dial back timing light here to set the bsse timing on a #honda #k20 engine prior to hitting the dyno. The dial back feature is handy for engines that only have a TDC mark - Instead of setting the timing to ‘0’ during this process and having an engine that struggles to idle, we can choose a more appropriate 10-15 degrees and then use the dial back function to compensate. Essentially when the timing mark is aligned, the number in the dial back screen is the actual timing which should match the laptop screen. There are also cheaper inductive timing lights that work perfectly well but don’t offer the dial back feature. #highperformaceacademy #learntotune

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by High Performance Academy in High Performance Academy with @arpbolts, @snapon_official, and @manleyperformance.

node.text:
The bolts and studs inside our engines are some of the most highly stressed fasteners we deal with so it goes without saying that making sure they are correctly tightened to the manufacturers specifications. This of course starts with a quality torque wrench, but it’s easy to take a torque wrench for granted and blindly believe the torque setting. Perhaps unsurprisingly if you’ve got an older torque wrench that’s been around the block a few times, or perhaps it’s taken a tumble off the workbench onto the floor, the accuracy can be questionable. 

If you’re tightening the wheel nuts on your car then the wheel is unlikely to fall off if the torque is slightly too high or too low, but taking this same approach to your conrod bolts could be playing with fire. All is not lost though as there are companies who specialise in checking and calibrating tools like your torque wrench. It’s usually recommended that your torque wrench is calibrated every 5000 cycles, but since counting your torque wrench cycles isn’t probably on the top of every engine builders mind, the simple rule of thumb is once every 12 months, or any time it may have taken a knock or a tumble off a bench. 

If your torque wrench is a mechanical ‘clicker-style’, then you should also get into the habit of adjusting it to the lowest torque setting before putting it in storage. Failings to do this will leave the internal spring under load which can weaken the spring over time and affect the wrenches accuracy. We know the torque wrench isn’t exactly the most exciting tool in our arsenal but with a few simple precautions we can be confident that we can rely on it to give us accurate results. #highperformanceacademy #enginebuilding101

node.text:
You can do so much with just a little data!

In tomorrow's [#FREELESSON] release we're going to dive into comparing 2 data logs, one from a professional driver and one from an amateur both in the same car, on the same track within the same day.

Using this data we'll show how easy it is to quickly identify data variances and use knowledge like that found in the Data Fundamentals Analysis course to determine the cause, giving valuable insight to our amateur driver on where they can focus effort to improve performance, in this case some easy attention to braking.

Make sure you are subscribed via the link in our bio to catch this one hot off the press.

#highperformanceacademy #racecraft #motorsport #datanerd #datavariance

node.text:
When it’s time to check your alignment there’s two paths you can go down. You can trust a professional alignment specialist or you can learn how to do it yourself. A professional can be a good option but this doesn’t give you much opportunity to make adjustments at the track if your current alignment turns out to be less than optimal. The alternative is to use a cost effective string alignment system and learn to do alignments yourself. 

While there are professional string alignment systems available that will set you back a few hundred dollars, there’s really nothing tricky about it and the setup we’re using here is less than $50 USD worth of parts plus the jack stands. The principle of string alignment is to set up a string line down each side of the car that’s parallel to the car centreline.

Once that’s done we can measure from the string to the front and rear of each wheel to calculate toe. On face value you might think using string is a bit ‘backyard-ish’ but it’s a technique you’ll see in the pits at the highest levels of motorsport, regardless of budget. 

#highperformanceacademy #fromthearchives #racecraft #alignment101 #strungout #learndriveoptimise

node.text:
Most people will be familiar with the normal style aftermarket adjustable strut tops seen on many modified cars with MacPherson strut-type suspension. The adjustment is usually limited to camber adjustment only where the strut top can be moved laterally to give different static camber settings. 

In this example, there is a second adjustment type shown in addition to the camber adjustment. The camber adjustment can be seen on the black sliding type slots, whereas the gold coloured adjusters allow the strut top to move forward and aft which affects the caster setting.

Caster is responsible for the self-centering effect you feel as a driver, where turning the wheel and releasing it makes the steering wheel want to return to the straight-ahead position. This is also has a relationship to the amount of steering wheel torque required by the driver when in a turn which can be fatiguing if it's too high. 

One of the less understood effects of increased caster is that it affects the amount of dynamic negative camber. The more caster you have, the more negative camber the front outside wheel will have for a given steering input. This has a big effect on the balance as camber is such a powerful tuning tool for tuning cornering balance. 

#highperformanceacademy #suspension #wheelalignment #caster #camber

node.text:
One of the critical clearances when building an engine is the piston to cylinder wall clearance. If we have insufficient clearance we risk the piston seizing in the bore as it heats up and expands. On the other hand if the clearance is too loose the piston will rock in the bore which creates noise, but this can also accelerate wear. This is a measurement that the machinist will set when the block is bored and honed, however it’s always a clearance that should be double checked during assembly. 

The process of checking the clearance starts with a micrometer which we use to measure the diameter of the piston skirt. Most people assume that the piston skirt is parallel from top to bottom but that’s not usually the case - The skirt is normally machined with a slight barrel shape to it so it’s important to measure the skirt at the correct point which we can find in the workshop manual. Once we have the micrometer locked up we can then use this to zero our dial bore gauge before finally inserting the bore gauge into the cylinder as shown. 

As the bore gauge is rocked back and forth in the bore, the dial indicator will then show us the clearance. It doesn’t end there though - By checking the clearance at the top, middle and the bottom of the bore we can also check for any taper or belling in the bores (ideally they should be parallel). By checking the bore in two locations at 90 degrees to each other we can also check for any out of round. 

It’s important to note that if the block has been torque plate honed then we also should have the torque plate installed when making these checks. #hoghperformanceacademy #enginebuilding101

node.text:
Analysing the performance of your vehicle is a critical step when it comes to corner weighting or setup adjustments, but what are some of the key areas you should focus on to check where your car is at?

This is one module from a full course that covers the corner weighting process from start to finish.

In this lesson which is taken from the Practical Corner Weighting course, Andre will cover some of the things he checks at his local track, Highlands Motorsport Park. After this step you will assess your vehicles set up and adjust accordingly, being mindful that you're not trying to fix oversteer or understeer issues that are actually driver induced handling errors.

For this test we're going to use a GG Diagram aka Traction Circle to also help give us an indication if the car is favouring one side or end over the other.

Note any testing should be started at a slow speed while you work up to full pace.

#highperformanceacademy #racecraft #learndriveoptimise #cornerweighting #highlandsmotorsportpark
